page.title: 17WOODLANDS STUBHAMPTON AREA
page.content: Early man destroyed the primary woodlands and now the whole area represents some form of planting, except for small areas of Quercus Robur (Oak) standards and Corylus Avellana(Hazel) coppice.Since 1900, planting has been of broad leaves with some softwoods.Fagus Sylvatica (Beech) dominate with Fraximus Excelsior (Ash) and Acer Pseudoplantus (Sycamore),the latter being subject to squirrel damage.The soft woods are Pinus Sylvestris (Scots Pine),P.Nigra (Austrian Pine) which suffer from chlovosis,various Larix Decidua (European Larch) and some stands of Picea Abies (Norway Spruce).The more recent plantings have been of Thuya Plicata (Western Red Cedar).The woods are managed now by the Forestry Commission and private owners primarilly for hardwood production.
